website_summaries.verdict: This Kodak VR camera is extraordinarily easy to use, fairly affordable, and takes quality videos, plus it comes bundled with a wide range of useful accessories to get you started.
pros: lens cover, carrying case, bar mount, battery, cleaning cloth
cons: of shooting 360° video in 4K, but you’ll maximize your battery life by using a lower resolution

website_summaries.verdict: The versatile Kodak Pixpro SP360 4K is a 360-degree camera and 4K-resolution action cam rolled into one. You'll need better software than what's provided to get the most from it, though.
pros: The Kodak Pixpro SP360 4K is a clear improvement over the original's video quality
Single-camera 360-degree video and photos don't require stitching
A Dual Pro Pack of cameras makes it possible to create spherical video with its bundled basic stitching software
Videos can be uploaded to YouTube and Facebook
Mobile app makes it easier to change settings and gives you a preview of your shot
cons: The Dual Pro Pack is priced for serious hobbyists and pros and will require better software than Kodak's included solutions for the best results
Included stitching software is for video only
The bundled dual-camera mount is a pain to use and no simple tripod mount is included

customer_reviews.title: Cool camera but splits continuous recordings
customer_reviews.text: Setup worked as instructed and it records as advertised. The video quality matches the marketing from Kodak which is great at day and acceptable at night. The photos taken are awesome. I would have given five stars if it would record continuous video. The 360sp 4K splits the video at 30 minutes or less based on file size. I was looking to record up to 2 hours continuous video and this wasn't in any of the specs I was able to find before buying. The battery life is ok at about 55 minutes minimum video recording. Overall still a cool camera.
customer_reviews.author: wnoel

customer_reviews.title: Not there yet.
customer_reviews.text: This product is just too early of a generation. Pros: nice quality images and videos from a 2 lens set up. Cons: It is so cumbersome to use. To take a full 360 video or picture you have to take the footage, download it to the computer, combine the files from each camera 1 at a time, then move ti to another program to edit it and render. There are too many products out there cheaper and produce something ready to go right out of camera. Accessories are expensive.
customer_reviews.author: Gregory Salvatore

customer_reviews.title: The next step for your photos. 360 degree views.
customer_reviews.text: This is the first camera that I really want to take pictures with. Its AUTOMATIC and you just point it and press record. Then once you get it to your computer, download it and choose the view that pleases you and then export. Yep, its 2 step but for 360 degree views and clarity its AWESOME. I got all the accessories too and when I had trouble, I called Kodak. They did not question me, they just sent out a new remote control that solved the problem.
customer_reviews.author: 111 Who Wants

customer_reviews.title: Overheats in 30 minutes under normal use.
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the dual unit since my original Kodak 360 was not 4k and I wanted to shoot full 360. Too bad the units overheat within 30 minutes and go into shutdown. Who shoots anything for only 30 minutes?!?! Now what do I do. Its a nice camera and the video take is also pretty clean but this time limitation is a deal breaker. Have to decide if I am going to return them or not. Buyer beware.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: I love my pix pro!
customer_reviews.text: If you're in between this camera and a goPro, I would say go with this one. I recently went on a photo trip with friends who had goPros and all footage came out amazing, but their colors were dull, matte, whilst mine were super real and saturated. Also, the camera automatically adjust exposure while recording, which helps A TON!

customer_reviews.title: Exciting technology, but early adoption has its drawbacks.
customer_reviews.text: Full review at [...] but essentially, while the product produces great results, using it is fiddly and you could decide ultimately too much hassle to make it worth it. You get a lot of kit included, but it costs a lot. Some of the best results I found were when the cameras was attached to the back of my car driving through redwoods. Sample of video at:  Two cameras being forced to work in tandem means compromises are required; a watch is required to control the cameras, rather than an app. Removing cameras from their housing is fiddly, but required every time you want to charge the cameras - which is a lot.
customer_reviews.author: Chris

customer_reviews.title: Good quality 4k VR camera for the price
customer_reviews.text: The Kodak PIXPRO SP360 is an good quality 4k camera for a good price. I’ve seen higher quality video, most of which are from much more expensive cameras. If you’re looking to make VR the PIXPRO is currently the only option I know of for the price. Overall the camera it’s self is easy to use and the Premier Pack comes with a several accessories. The accessories are for attaching the camera to different objects similar to GoPro accessories. I found that software provided for editing a little confusing and some what lacking in function. With a little learning curve you should be able to edit the video with very few problems.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick

customer_reviews.title: Definitely worth getting 4k vs regular sp360
customer_reviews.text: The 4k version of this camera (the black one) definitely gives more satisfactory results vs the regular sp360 (the yellow one). I also have a dirt cheap knockoff "360" camera and find the battery life and ease of use on the kodak to be significantly better.
customer_reviews.author: The Sylvans

customer_reviews.title: Easy and User Friendly
customer_reviews.text: This single lens 360 camera is the perfect solution for anyone who wants to start shooting 360 video without having to be too technically savvy in this new 360 video world. I recommend using the app when working with one camera. Also sharing to Facebook and Youtube is easy... just render with the software and upload. The Dual Pro Pack is more for the tech savvy type, although after doing it once, you will feel like anyone can do it. Stitching Two video files without the PIXPRO Software would cost you more time and money. The provided software is amazing if you know what it takes to get 360 video without it. Definitely the best value on the market.
customer_reviews.author: Kevin

customer_reviews.title: Not sure why this is getting such terrible reviews. For the money
customer_reviews.text: Not sure why this is getting such terrible reviews. For the money, you get an incredible package and it's extremely portable. A hobbyist may be flustered by this but if you're used to getting things up and running, this is a cinch. The cameras are incredibly good and the whole package is flexible.
customer_reviews.author: Consideration

customer_reviews.title: Not so user friendly, may want to avoid unless you're really good at tweaking/working with tech
customer_reviews.text: As many of the other reviews have mentioned, it might be better to wait until a more easy-to-use device comes out - one with more user friendly software. We've tries playing around with this a few times over the past few weeks and ended up giving up because of our frustration level trying to get everything to work smoothly. I think if you're a super tech type person who likes to tinker around and fine tune devices/software to get things to work then you may be just fine with this. However, if you're looking for something to essentially run right out of the box plug and play style then don't bother.

customer_reviews.title: Don't waste your money.
customer_reviews.text: This camera does not deliver. The footage is ok (4K doesn't look very good no matter what you do when trying to cover 360), but the firmware and the accompanying software kill it. USB connections are spotty, especially with Macs, wireless is too slow, and the editing/viewing software that comes with the camera is buggy and pretty much unusable. I would not recommend buying this camera to anyone. I would be personally embarrassed to be a software developer on the team that developed the editing software. How could you think for a minute that it was even consumer quality?
